questions.explanation:

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Low CSF pleocytosis (< 2/ul) Is a good prognostic marker Cryptococcus gelatinous capsule stains bright pink with mucicarmine stain and discriminates the organism from Histoplasma and blastomycosis. India ink stain particles are extruded by the gelatinous capsule and hence only the background is stained. In cryptococcal meningitis Signs of meningeal irritation like meningismus may be absent In cryptococcal meningitis, CSF examination usually reveals evidence of chronic meningitis with mononuclear cell pleocytosis and increased protein levels. A particularly useful test is cryptococcal antigen (CRAg) detection in CSF and blood. The assay is based on serologic detection of cryptococcal polysaccharide and is both sensitive and specific . A positive cryptococcal antigen test provides strong presumptive evidence for cryptococcosis

questions.text: While discharging a patient of meningitis due to H. influenza the essential step you will perform is:

Solution:

Since the overall risk of SNHL is significant in children with meningitis , it is recommended that BERA be recorded , so that early intervention may be possible. Nontypeable H. influenzae is one of the three most common causes of childhood otitis media (the other two being Streptococcus pneumoniae and Moraxella catarrhalis). The diagnosis is made by pneumatic otoscopy. An etiologic diagnosis, although not routinely sought, can be established by tympanocentesis and culture of middle-ear fluid. A diagnosis of otitis media is based on the detection by pneumatic otoscopy of fluid in the middle ear and bilateral evoked auditory response.

questions.text: A 1 year old child presents with a history of fever, coryza and dry cough for 4 days followed by the appearance of a rash. The rash of measles begins as erythematous macules behind the ears and on the neck and hairline. The rash progresses to involve the face, trunk, and arms, with involvement of the legs and feet by the end of the second day. Areas of confluent rash appear on the trunk and extremities, and petechiae may be present. The rash fades slowly in the same order of progression as it appeared, usually beginning on the third or fourth day after onset.

This state of immune suppression enhances susceptibility to secondary infections with bacteria and viruses that cause pneumonia and diarrhea and is responsible for a substantial proportion of measles-related morbidity and deaths. Lab investigations revealed the following: Hb-11.2g/dl TLC-12800 cells/mm3 Platelet count-1.8lakh cells/mm3 BUN-32 mg/dl S creatinine-1.1mg/dl TSH-2.3 miu/ml HbA1C-8.2% What is the CURB-65 score of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4 In this patient No confusion- 0 points BUN >20 mg/dl- 1 point Respiratory rate>30- 1 point BP <90/60mmHg- 1 point Age >65- 1 point So, total score 4 and he needs ICU admission.

Highyeild:

CURB 65 COMPONENT SCORE CONFUSION 1 UREA>30mg/dl (BUN>20mg/dl) 1 RESPIRATORY RATE 1 BLOOD PRESSURE SBP<90mmHg OR DBP<60mmhg 1 AGE >65years 1 Total score 5 If score is 0,1➡️Outpatient treatment If score is 2 ➡️Hospitalization If score 4, 5➡️ICU admission

questions.text: A 45 year old male , who has recently recovered from an influenza infection, Now presents with fever, cough for 4 days and episodes of hemoptysis. Chest x-ray shows multiple patchy infiltrates. Sputum AFB is negative. Covid RTPCR is negative. Subsequently, he develops respiratory distress and a repeat chest x-ray shows the presence of a massive right pleural effusion. Which of the following organisms causes these features
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Staphylococcus aureus Features that suggest MRSA pneumonia are:- Cavitary infiltration/necrosis Rapidly increasing pleural effusion Gross hemoptysis Post Influenza infection Neutropenia Erythematous rash Skin pustules This patient has a history of recent influenza infection and subsequently develops features of pneumonia associated with hemoptysis and rapid development of pleural effusion. Hence most likely organism is Staphylococcus aureus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Klebsiella pneumonia is common in alcoholics and presents with red currant jelly sputum Option: B. It is the most common cause of pneumonia however the presence of hemoptysis, rapidly developing effusion favours staph aureus as diagnosis Option: C. Occurs in patients with risk factors such as recent ship travel/hotel stay and is associated with diarrhoea and hyponatremia .

questions.text: A 49 year old male is a known case of bronchiectasis. He presents with a history of fever and increased cough in the last 1 week. Chest x-ray shows features of consolidation. Bronchiectasis is a risk factor for pneumonia with all the following organisms EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Streptococcus pneumoniae The possible pathogens for patients with structural lung disease like bronchiectasis are:- Pseudomonas Burkholderia Staph aureus Streptococcus pneumonia is to be considered as the possible pathogen in alcoholics, COPD and it is the most common cause of pneumonia.

Highyeild:

Epidemiologic Factors Suggesting Possible Causes of Community-Acquired Pneumonia FACTOR POSSIBLE PATHOGEN(S) Alcoholism Streptococcus pneumoniae, oral anaerobes, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Acinetobacter spp., Mycobacterium tuberculosis COPD and/or smoking Haemophilus influenza, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Legionella spp., S. pneumoniae, Moraxella catarrhalis, Chlamydia pneumoniae Structural lung disease (e.g., bronchiectasis) P. aeruginosa, Burkholderia cepacia, Staphylococcus aureus Dementia, stroke, decreased level of consciousness Oral anaerobes, gram-negative enteric bacteria Lung abscess CA-MRSA, oral anaerobes, endemic fungi, M. tuberculosis, atypical mycobacteria Travel to Ohio or St. Lawrence river valley Histoplasma capsulatum Travel to southwestern United States Hantavirus, Coccidioides spp. Travel to Southeast Asia Burkholderia pseudomallei, avian influenza virus Stay in a hotel or on a cruise ship in the previous 2 weeks Legionella spp. Local influenza activity Influenza virus, S. pneumoniae, S. aureus Exposure to bats or birds H. capsulatum Exposure to birds Chlamydia psittaci Exposure to rabbits Francisella tularensis Exposure to sheep, goats, parturient cats Coxiella burnetii Abbreviations: CA-MRSA, community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus; COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

questions.text: A 35 Year old was admitted under the medicine department with a diagnosis of CAP. He received IV antibiotics for 5 days and was discharged subsequently. He has now come for the follow-up to the OPD 1-week post-discharge. He has no symptoms but repeated chest x-rays show persistent opacities. What is the usual time taken for chest radiographic abnormalities to resolve?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4-12 weeks Fever and leukocytosis usually resolve within 2-4 days in otherwise healthy patients of CAP , but physical findings may last longer. Chest radiographic abnormalities are slowest to resolve (4-12 weeks) with speed of resolution depending on the patient's age and underlying lung disease For a hospitalized patient, a follow-up radiograph ~4-6 weeks later is recommended. If relapse or recurrence is documented, particularly in the same lung segment, the possibility of underlying neoplasm must be considered.

questions.text: A 41 year old male k/c/o T2DM since 5 years presents with a history of fever and cough for 1 week. CXR shows features of right lower zone consolidation. Subsequently, after a few days, he complains of dyspnea and a repeat CXR done shows rt-sided pleural effusion. The physician feels it is most likely syn pneumonic effusion and orders a diagnostic pleural tap. All the following features of pleural fluid given below require chest tube insertion EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glucose <6 mmol/l A significant pleural effusion should be tapped for both diagnostic and therapeutic Pleural fluid should be completely drained; A chest tube is often required if the pleural fluid has the following characteristics :- pH < 7 Glucose < 2.2mmol/l LDH >1000 U/L bacteria are seen on gram stain/cultured

questions.text: You are posted in the medical ICU and the intensivist questions you regarding all the possible steps which can be taken for the prevention of VAP. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding prevention of VAP?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Delayed tracheostomy Microaspirations around the endotracheal tube and altered swallowing functions are important risk factors for VAP. Hence early tracheostomy is encouraged if the patient cannot be weaned off the ventilator and shows no clinical improvement

Highyeild:

"Strategies with negative randomized trials or conflicting results

Hence postpyloric enteral feeding, avoidance of high gastric residues and prokinetic agents must be used.

questions.text: A 48 year old diabetic patient is admitted with the diagnosis of CAP. Sputum culture done reveals atypical organism as the cause of pneumonia. Atypical organisms causing pneumonia can be treated by all of the following agents EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Beta lactams The atypical organisms causing pneumonia include Mycoplasma pneumoniae Chlamydia pneumoniae Legionella spp Respiratory viruses such as:- influenza, adenovirus, human metapneumovirus , RSV

Extraedge:

These atypical organisms are intrinsically resistant to all B lactam antibiotics and must be treated with any of the following Fluoroquinolones Macrolides Tetracycline In 10-15% of CAP cases that are polymicrobial,the etiology usually includes a combination of typical and atypical organisms Options B,C & D Are Ruled Out.

questions.text: An 8 year old child presented with fever and cough since 1 week. CXR done is shown below. What is the likely etiological agent ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Streptococcus pneumoniae The image shows a spherical consolidation with air bronchogram suggestive of ‘round pneumonia’ caused by streptococcus pneumoniae The radiographic appearance of pneumococcal pneumonia is varied. It classically consists of lobar or segmental consolidation but in some cases is patchy In children, ’round pneumonia ” a distinctly spherical consolidation on CXR is associated with pneumococcal etiology

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Pneumonia due to listeria is uncommon in adults it usually causes gastroenteritis meningoencephalitis and infection in pregnant women and neonates . Option: B.Coxiella burnetii causes Q fever. The pneumonic form of the illness can range from very mild-to-severe pneumonia requiring assisted ventilation. Multiple round opacities are a common finding on chest radiography. Option: D.Staphylococcus aureus can cause lung abscesses and even necrotising pneumonia and pneumatoceles . MRSA can be a cause of HAP/VAP.

questions.text: A 40 year old male known case of diabetes, and hypertension presents to the medicine OPD with a history of fever and cough for 1 week. He is hemodynamically stable. He gives a history of hospitalization for diabetic foot 1 month ago for which he received parenteral antibiotics. As per ATS 2019 guidelines, which of these will be the optimal OPD treatment for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Tab amoxicillin 500mg TID for 7 days + tab azithromycin 500 mg OD for 3 days

options.label: C
options.text: Tab Amoxicillin/clavulanate 500 mg/125 mg three times daily for 5- 7 days + Tab azithromycin 500mg for 3 days

options.label: D
options.text: Tab levofloxacin 500 mg od for 5 days

questions.correct_answer: C. Tab Amoxicillin/clavulanate 500 mg/125 mg three times daily for 5- 7 days + Tab azithromycin 500mg for 3 days
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tab Amoxicillin/clavulanate 500 mg/125 mg three times daily for 5- 7 days + Tab azithromycin 500mg for 3 days This patient has associated comorbidities and also has received antibiotics in the past 3 months. As per ATS 2019 guidelines: For outpatient adults with comorbidities such as chronic heart, lung, liver, or renal disease; diabetes mellitus; alcoholism; malignancy; or asplenia we recommend (in no particular order of preference) : Combination therapy: amoxicillin/clavulanate 500 mg/125 mg three times daily, or amoxicillin/ clavulanate 875 mg/125 mg twice daily, or 2,000 mg/125 mg twice daily, or a cephalosporin (cefpodoxime 200 mg twice daily or cefuroxime 500 mg twice daily) AND macrolide (azithromycin 500 mg on first day then 250 mg daily, clarithromycin [500 mg twice daily or extended-release 1,000 mg once daily]) or doxycycline 100 mg twice daily (conditional recommendation, low quality of evidence for combination therapy); Monotherapy : respiratory fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin 750 mg daily, moxifloxacin 400 mg daily, or gemifloxacin 320 mg daily). Therefore this patient should receive. Tab Amoxicillin/clavulanate 500 mg/125 mg three times daily for 5- 7 days + Tab azithromycin 500mg for 3 days.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Monotherapy with doxycycline is given with patients with no co-morbidities and no prior antibiotics in the last 3 months. This patient has received antibiotics 1 month ago Option: B. Amoxicillin 1g TID can be used along with azithromycin . Amoxicillin 500mg is mentioned in the option and is the wrong dose. Option: D. The dose of levofloxacin monotherapy is 750 mg and not 500mg

questions.text: A 45 year old male is admitted to the ward with a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia. He has no known comorbidities and no history of past hospital admissions. He is hemodynamically stable. Which of the following would be an appropriate antibiotic regimen for him?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ceftriaxone 1g+doxycycline 100mg BD This patient is being treated in a patient non ICU care. It is a non-severe pneumonia He has a low risk for antibiotic resistance The regimens approved for empirical inpatient treatment of CAP with low risk for antibiotic resistance are(ATS 2019 guidelines): Ceftriaxone 1g iv daily +doxycycline PO 100mg for 7 days Ceftriaxone 1g iv daily +IV/oral azithromycin for 3 days Levofloxacin 750 mg IV for 5 days For ICU patients: Ceftriaxone 1g iv BD+ IV azithromycin for 3 days
